questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022)

 

  1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
  2. Baby on artificial feeds
  3. Baby of working mother/single parent
  4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
  5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Among the given options, babies on artificial feeds and babies of working/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

 

 

It is important to identify children at risk and give special intensive care. This is done because these children contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abortion: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.

 

Option C. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission 

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission. Perinatal transmission, also known as vertical transmission, occurs during labor and delivery. This can happen when the newborn is exposed to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal.

 

Mechanisms of HIV Transmission in Infants:

 

  • In utero (During pregnancy): HIV can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
  • During delivery (Perinatal): This is the most common mode of transmission and occurs when the baby is exposed to infected blood and secretions during the birthing process.
  • After birth by breastfeeding: This is a less common mode of transmission compared to perinatal transmission but still significant, especially in regions where breastfeeding is essential for infant nutrition.

 

Risk Factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast milk: While breast milk can transmit HIV, it is less common compared to perinatal transmission during delivery.

 

Option C. Transplacental: HIV can be transmitted transplacentally during pregnancy, but this is not as common as perinatal transmission.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion with infected blood: This is a rare cause of HIV infection in newborns compared to perinatal transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

 

The image shows a lower limb ulcer in a patient with a history of leprosy. This type of ulcer is typically neuropathic or trophic due to nerve damage caused by leprosy, leading to decreased sensation and subsequent injury. The first and most crucial step in managing such ulcers is debridement and proper dressing. Debridement removes necrotic tissue, slough, and any other debris, which promotes a clean wound environment conducive to healing. Proper dressing keeps the ulcer protected and aids in healing by maintaining an optimal moisture balance.

 

Subsequent steps after debridement include appropriate foot care, offloading pressure from the affected area, and limb rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. However, the immediate next step is to clean the wound, making debridement and dressing the correct initial intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) is the treatment for leprosy to address the underlying infection but does not directly contribute to the healing of an existing ulcer. While MDT is crucial for treating leprosy, it does not manage the wound directly and should not be the first step in ulcer management.

 

Option C. Foot care, limb rehabilitation: Foot care and rehabilitation are essential components of managing neuropathic ulcers, especially in preventing further injuries and recurrences. However, these measures alone will not heal an existing dirty or necrotic ulcer. The ulcer must be cleaned and dressed first before these steps can be effective.

 

Option D. Deformity correction: This will help in healing of ulcer at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harpers 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

 

Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. In this case, the patient presents with massive splenomegaly, fever, anemia, and other features suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India. The vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania is the Phlebotomus species, commonly known as sandflies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rat fly: Rat flies are not vectors for Leishmania. They are typically associated with the spread of different diseases, like murine typhus, but not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Chrysops fly: Chrysops flies are known as deer flies and are vectors for diseases like Loiasis but are not involved in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Option D. Black fly: Black flies are vectors for Onchocerciasis (river blindness) and have no role in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

choices.text: Conservative management is the mainstay therapy
Posture of finger is in extension
Pain on passive extension of finger

questions.text: True about acute tenosynovitis is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive extension of finger

 

ACUTE SUPPURATIVE TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • It is purulent infection of synovial flexor sheath.
  • It may be the result of the spread of adjacent pulp infections or puncture wounds in the flexor creases.

 

 

  • Although the flexor sheath is usually involved, the radial and ulnar bursae may be involved as well.
  • Most common organism Staphylococcus aureus
  • Most common digits involved Ring, middle and index fingers
  • Kanavels sign:
    • Rigid positioning of finger in flexion
    • Tenderness over tendon sheath (most significant)
    • Severe pain on passive extension of involved digit
    • Fusiform swelling of involved digit

 

 

  • Treatment
    • Immediate treatment with antibiotics and splinting may abort spread of the infection, if symptoms present for less than 48 hours.
    • Established pyogenic tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency prompt surgical drainage along with antibiotics.
    • If drainage is required, an open or closed irrigation technique can be used.
    • If an open technique is used, healing and rehabilitation are prolonged, and full motion may not be regained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management is the mainstay therapy. This statement is false. They gold standard treatment is irrigation and debridement of the flexor sheath.

 

Option B. More commonly involves thumb. This is statement is incorrect. The index, middle and ring fingers are more commonly involved.

 

Option C. Posture of finger is in extension. This statement is incorrect. The affected finger remains in flexion. There is pain on active or passive extension of the finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute suppurative tenosynovitis of the finger is a purulent infection of the flexor tendon sheath of the finger.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC MRI of the orbit

 

TOC mild moderate disease conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease first line TOC CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the fathers death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their sons, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of either parent. In this scenario, the child was born 8 months after the father's death, which fits the definition of a posthumous child. The grandparents doubted the childs legitimacy, but DNA testing confirmed the biological connection, validating the child's status as the deceased father's offspring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppositious child: A suppositious child is a term used to describe a fraudulent or fake child who is falsely presented as an heir, often to claim property or inheritance. This does not apply in this case because the DNA test confirmed the childs legitimacy as the biological offspring.

 

Option B. Fictitious child: A fictitious child is purely an imaginary or invented figure that does not exist in reality, often found in literature or imagination. This term is unrelated to the case as it refers to nonexistent entities, unlike the real, biologically confirmed child in question.

 

Option D. Illegitimate child: An illegitimate child is one born outside of marriage or not legally recognized as belonging to the mother's husband. In this case, the DNA test confirmed that the child is indeed the biological offspring of the deceased father, making the term irrelevant here.

 

Educational Objective:


A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the least common opportunistic fungus known to cause pulmonary infections in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sporothrix

 

Explanation:

 

Sporothrix is the least common opportunistic fungus among the given options to cause pulmonary infections in children. Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes sporotrichosis, which is typically a cutaneous infection that follows traumatic inoculation of the fungus into the skin, often through rose thorns or splinters (hence its nickname "rose gardener's disease"). Pulmonary sporotrichosis is extremely rare, especially in children, and is not typically considered among the common opportunistic pulmonary fungal infections.

 

 

The other listed fungi are more commonly associated with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect. Aspergillus is a common cause of opportunistic pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with prolonged neutropenia, chronic granulomatous disease, or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy. It can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and aspergilloma.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect. Cryptococcus (particularly C. neoformans) is a significant cause of pulmonary and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with HIV/AIDS or on immunosuppressive therapy. Pulmonary cryptococcosis is more common than pulmonary sporotrichosis.

 

Option D. Mucor - Incorrect. Mucor species (causing mucormycosis) are increasingly recognized as important opportunistic fungi in immunocompromised children, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, prolonged neutropenia, or those receiving deferoxamine therapy. Rhinocerebral and pulmonary mucormycosis are the most common clinical presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes cutaneous sporotrichosis following traumatic inoculation and is rarely associated with pulmonary infections in children, unlike Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, and Mucor species, which are more common opportunistic pulmonary pathogens in immunocompromised pediatric patients.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior vena cava

 

The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (caf au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called coast of Maine borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called Rind sign.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of chondroblasts with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called chicken wire calcification are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic jailhouse (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a polka dot pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

 

The image shows a tracheostomy tube, which is not used for upper airway examination.

 

Tracheostomy:

 

  • It is a procedure where alternative airway is established when normal airway is compromised.
  • An opening is made on the anterior wall of trachea and a tube is inserted, through which air exchange occurs between lungs and outside.
  • It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
  • Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
  • High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.
  • In emergency tracheostomy, vertical incision is taken but in elective cases, horizontal incision is taken.
  • It is generally a temporary procedure till the pathology in the upper bypassed airway clears.
  • In some cases, like cancer larynx where laryngectomy was done, permanent tracheostomy is done.
  • Removal of tracheostomy tube is called decannulation.
  • Different types of tracheostomy tubes PVC, Metallic (Chevalier-Jackson), etc.
  • Complications of tracheostomy surgical emphysema, hemorrhage, Apnea due to CO2 washout, Pneumothorax, Tube displacement, Tube blockage, Tracheomalacia, Subglottic stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Primary Uses of a Tracheostomy Tube Include:

 

Option A. Airway Toileting: Facilitates the removal of secretions from the airways.

 

Option C. Acute Nasopharyngeal Obstruction: Provides an airway bypass in cases of blockage in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation: Offers a secure, stable method for long-term ventilation support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.
